title: Test Your Understanding: JavaScript Promises and Async/Await
description: See how well you understood the concepts in this post!

questions.question: What are the three states of a Promise?
questions.explanation: Promises have three states: pending (initial state), fulfilled (successfully completed), and rejected (failed). Note that 'resolved' is often used informally, but the correct term is 'fulfilled'.

questions.question: What does the .then() method return?
questions.explanation: The .then() method returns a new Promise, which allows for Promise chaining. This is why you can chain multiple .then() calls together.

questions.question: Which of the following are Promise combinator methods?
questions.explanation: Promise.all(), Promise.race(), Promise.allSettled(), and Promise.any() are all Promise combinator methods. Promise.map() does not exist in JavaScript.

questions.question: async/await is just syntactic sugar over Promises.
questions.explanation: True! async/await is syntactic sugar that makes Promise-based code easier to read and write. Under the hood, it still uses Promises and the event loop.

questions.question: What happens if you use await in a non-async function?

options.text: It works fine, await can be used anywhere
SyntaxError - await can only be used in async functions
The code runs but await is ignored

questions.explanation: You'll get a SyntaxError. The await keyword can only be used inside async functions (or at the top level of modules with top-level await support).

questions.question: What is the main difference between Promise.all() and Promise.allSettled()?

options.text: Promise.all() runs sequentially, Promise.allSettled() runs in parallel
Promise.all() fails fast if any Promise rejects, Promise.allSettled() waits for all regardless
Promise.all() only works with arrays, Promise.allSettled() works with objects

questions.explanation: Promise.all() fails fastâ€”if any Promise rejects, the entire operation rejects immediately. Promise.allSettled() waits for all Promises to settle (fulfill or reject) and returns results for all of them, never rejecting.

questions.question: What happens when you forget to use await with an async function call?

options.text: You get the Promise object instead of the resolved value

questions.explanation: If you forget await, you get the Promise object itself (in pending state) rather than the resolved value. This is a common source of bugs where you try to use a Promise as if it were the actual value.
